revision.text:
[[File:Medium Guppy.png|thumb|Mrs Tebb (left), [[Georgiana Houghton]] (middle), Agnes Guppy-Volckman (right).]]
'''Agnes Guppy-Volckman''' (1838–1917) was a British spiritualist [[Mediumship|medium]].<ref>Anderson, Rodger. (2006). ''Psychics, Sensitives and Somnambules: A Biographical Dictionary with Bibliographies''. McFarland. p. 75. {{ISBN|978-0786427703}}</ref>
==Career==
She was born Agnes Elisabeth White in [[Regent's Park]], London.<ref>Noakes, Richard John. (2004). ''Guppy [formerly Nicholl; other married name Guppy-Volckman], (Agnes) Elisabeth (1838–1917), medium''. Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.</ref> She was known as Miss Agnes Nichol, later becoming the second wife of the [[Spiritualism|spiritualist]] Samuel Guppy in 1867. After the death of Guppy in 1875, she married William Volckman.<ref>[[Frank Podmore|Podmore, Frank]]. (2011, reprint edition). ''Modern Spiritualism: A History and a Criticism, Volume 2''. Cambridge University Press. pp. 63–95. {{ISBN|978-1-108-07258-8}}</ref>
Guppy-Volckman was discovered by [[Alfred Russel Wallace]] in 1866 and managed to dupe him into believing she could communicate with spirits.<ref>[http://archive.randi.org/site/index.php/swift-blog/1935-alfred-russel-wallace-and-the-medium.html "Alfred Russel Wallace And The Medium"]. James Randi Educational Foundation.</ref> Volckman was associated with the fraudulent spirit photographer [[Frederick Hudson (photographer)|Frederick Hudson]].<ref name="Pearsall 1972">[[Ronald Pearsall|Pearsall, Ronald]]. (1972). ''The Table-Rappers''. Book Club Associates. pp. 82–122. {{ISBN|978-0750936842}}</ref><ref>Slotten, Ross A. (2004). ''The Heretic in Darwin's Court: The Life of Alfred Russel Wallace''. Columbia University Press. p. 316. {{ISBN|978-0-231-13010-3}}</ref><ref>[[Joe Nickell|Nickell, Joe]]. (2012). ''The Science of Ghosts: Searching for Spirits of the Dead''. Prometheus Books. pp. 301–302. {{ISBN|978-1-61614-585-9}}</ref> She was known for producing [[Apport (paranormal)|apports]] and [[Materialization (paranormal)|materializations]]. Researcher [[Ronald Pearsall]] described the fraudulent techniques that Guppy-Volckman used in her séances.<ref name="Pearsall 1972"/>
[[John Grant (author)|John Grant]] has written that she "was a clever charlatan; her stunts bear all the hallmarks of extravagant stage conjuring tricks."<ref>Grant, John. (2015). ''Spooky Science: Debunking the Pseudoscience of the Afterlife''. Sterling Publishing. p. 13. {{ISBN|978-1-4549-1654-3}}</ref>
[[Molly Whittington-Egan]] has written a biography of Guppy-Volckman.<ref>Whittington-Egan, Molly. (2015). ''Mrs Guppy Takes A Flight: A Scandal of Victorian Spiritualism''. Neil Wilson Publishing. {{ISBN|978-1-906000-87-5}}</ref>
==Alleged levitation==
On June 3rd, 1871 it was alleged that Volckman had [[Levitation (paranormal)|levitated]] out of her own house in [[Highbury]] three miles away to a séance room table in [[Lamb's Conduit Street]]. Although this incident was considered genuine by spiritualists such as [[Arthur Conan Doyle]] and [[A. Campbell Holms]], it was dismissed by skeptics as a hoax.<ref>[[Arthur Conan Doyle|Doyle, Arthur Conan]]. (1930). ''The Edge of the Unknown''. New York, Putnam's. p. 32</ref><ref>[[Joseph McCabe|McCabe, Joseph]]. (1920). ''Spiritualism: A Popular History From 1847''. Dodd, Mead & Company. p. 144. McCabe described the case as a "piece of collusive trickery."</ref><ref>[[Harry Price|Price, Harry]]. (1942). ''Search for Truth: My Life for Psychical Research''. Collins. p. 246. Price suggests the séance sitters "were probably in the plot."</ref><ref>[[Simeon Edmunds|Edmunds, Simeon]]. (1966). ''Spiritualism: A Critical Survey''. Aquarian Press. p. 104</ref><ref>[[Ruth Brandon|Brandon, Ruth]]. (1983). ''The Spiritualists: The Passion for the Occult in the Nineteenth and Twentieth Centuries''. Weidenfeld and Nicolson. p. 105. {{ISBN|0-297-78249-5}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== *Anonymous. (1875). ''Spiritualism Exposed, or Lighting up a Dark Seance''. Birmingham. *Molly Whittington-Egan. (2015). ''Mrs Guppy Takes A Flight: A Scandal of Victorian Spiritualism''. Neil Wilson Publishing. {{ISBN|978-1-906000-87-5}}
{{Spiritism and Spiritualism}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Guppy-Volckman, Agnes}} [[Category:1838 births]] [[Category:1917 deaths]] [[Category:English spiritual mediums]] [[Category:Spiritualists]]

{{merge to|Chinese Americans|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox ethnic group | group = American-born Chinese | image = | pop = '''1,830,760'''{{cite web |url = http://www.pewsocialtrends.org/fact-sheet/asian-americans-chinese-in-the-u-s/ |publisher=Pew Research Centre|accessdate=5 October 2018}}
'''0.55%''' of the U.S. population (2015) | regions = [[New York metropolitan area|New York City Area]], [[Boston]], [[Delaware Valley|Philadelphia]], [[Washington metropolitan area|Washington DC]], [[North Jersey|Northern New Jersey]], [[San Francisco Bay Area]], [[Greater Los Angeles Area|Los Angeles Area]], [[San Diego]], [[Sacramento]], [[Houston]], [[Dallas–Fort Worth metroplex]], [[Austin, Texas|Austin]], [[Tampa]], [[Orlando]], [[Seattle metropolitan area|Seattle]], [[Atlanta]], [[Metro Detroit]], [[Honolulu]], [[Portland, Oregon]], [[Las Vegas]], [[Minneapolis]], [[Columbus, Ohio|Columbus]], [[Chicago metropolitan area|Chicago]], [[Phoenix, Arizona|Phoenix]] | langs = Predominantly [[English language|English]], [[varieties of Chinese]] | rels = [[Irreligion in the United States|Unaffiliated]], [[Buddhism in the United States|Buddhism]], [[Protestantism in the United States|Protestantism]], [[Catholic Church in the United States|Catholicism]],{{cite web |url = http://www.pewforum.org/Asian-Americans-A-Mosaic-of-Faiths-overview.aspx |title=Asian Americans: A Mosaic of Faiths |date=19 July 2012 |work = The Pew Forum on Religion & Public Life |publisher=Pew Research Center |accessdate=15 February 2013 |quote = Unaffiliated 52%, Protestant 22%, Buddhist 15%, Catholic 8% }} and [[Taoism in the United States|Taoism]] | related = [[Asian Americans]],
[[Overseas Chinese]], [[Chinese Canadians]] }} '''American-born Chinese''' or '''ABC''' ({{Zh|c=|s=美国出生华裔|t=美國出生華裔|p=Měiguó chūshēng huáyì}}) is a term widely used to refer to American citizens of Chinese descent, excluding first-generation immigrants. It is therefore a sub-category of the term [[Chinese American]], the latter of which also includes those who were born in Hong Kong, Mainland China, and Taiwan but naturalized as U.S. citizens. == Contested usage == According to some, the term has [[Perpetual Foreigner]] connotations. It has been noted that the term differs from existing patterns of immigrant designation in American English. For example, [[Peter Thiel]] is considered a "German-born American," and [[Elon Musk]] is considered a "South African-born American." In both of these cases, the first demographic word refers to the person's citizenship at birth, and the second refers to his citizenship at present. However, in the case of "American-born Chinese," the first demographic word refers to the subject's citizenship at birth (or at present) and the second to his (or her) race.{{Cite web|url=http://sar.network/read/abc-is-derogatory|title=Sino American Reunion (SAR)|last=|first=|date=|website=sar.network|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} It has also been observed that, in practice, the term American-born Chinese includes hundreds of thousands of Americans of Chinese descent who were, technically speaking, not born in America, but rather, we brought over by their parents at a young age. This indicates that the term may be a [[misnomer]]. == Demographics == {{Expand section|date=June 2018}} In differing degrees, many ABCs draw together Chinese family culture with American societal culture, developing a transnational life and identity.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QtCwzg6sIX0C|title=The Transnational History of a Chinese Family: Immigrant Letters, Family Business, and Reverse Migration|last=Liu|first=Haiming|date=|publisher=Rutgers University Press|year=2005|isbn=9780813535975|location=New Brunswick|pages=163-209|language=en}} However, this begins to shift in subsequent generations as families structures change through [[Interracial marriage in the United States|interracial marriage]]. In 2000, approximately 45% of American-born Chinese marry non-[[Chinese Americans]]; this is contrasted with [[Chinese Americans]] more generally, whereby 81.5% of men and 77.9% of women married other Chinese Americans.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R4D6uiswsnUC|title=Chinese America: Stereotype and Reality: History, Present, and Future of the Chinese Americans|last=Zinzius|first=Birgit|date=|publisher=Peter Lang|year=2005|isbn=9780820467443|location=New York|pages=217-218|language=en}} == Pop culture == The term has been used in the 2006 [[comic book]] by [[Gene Luen Yang]], entitled ''[[American Born Chinese]]''. It draws together the stories of three seemingly unrelated characters: Jin Wang, who moves into a new school and neighborhood to find he is the only [[Chinese American]]; the [[Sun Wukong|Monkey King]] of the Chinese fable ''[[Journey to the West]]''; and Danny, who has yearly visits from his Chinese cousin Chin-Kee which ruins his life.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=N0Cw-UWd7mEC|title=American Born Chinese|last=Yang|first=Gene Luen|date=2006|publisher=First Second|year=|isbn=9781429969369|location=New York|pages=|language=en}}{{Cite web|url=https://blogs.miamioh.edu/aaa201/2015/05/american-born-chinese-4/|title=American Born Chinese|last=Beebe|first=Nathaniel|date=May 9, 2015|website=AAA 201: Introduction to Asian/Asian American Studies, Miami University|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=June 15, 2018}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==See also== {{Portal|Asian Americans|China}} * [[Demographics of the United States]] * [[List of Chinese Americans]] * [[Jook-sing]] (竹升) is a Cantonese term for an overseas Chinese person who was born in a Western environment and/or a Chinese person who more readily or strongly identifies with Western culture than traditional Chinese culture. {{Chinese American}} {{DEFAULTSORT:American-Born Chinese}} [[Category:Asian-American issues]] [[Category:Chinese people|*]] [[Category:Chinese American]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2018}} {{cleanup rewrite|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Angel Haze | image = Angel Haze.jpg | caption = Wilson performing in October 2012 | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Raeen-Roes Wilson | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|mf=yes|1994|7|10}}<!-- per cited source, Angel Haze was born in 1994 https://www.theguardian.com/music/2014/feb/21/angel-haze-interview-my-mum-knew-i-would-tell-everything --> | birth_place = [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]], U.S.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rap-up.com/2013/01/03/azealia-banks-and-angel-haze-trade-shots-on-twitter/ |title=Azealia Banks and Angel Haze trade shots on Twitter |publisher=Rap-Up.com |date= |accessdate=December 4, 2013}}</ref> | origin = [[Brooklyn, New York|Brooklyn]], [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S.<ref name="xxlmag">{{cite web | url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2015/03/33-rappers-reppin-different-hometown-city/ | title= 33 Rappers Reppin' A City Where They Weren't Born | work= xxlmag| publisher= Dan Rys| accessdate= October 6, 2018}}</ref> | genre = [[Hip hop music|Hip hop]] | years_active = 2012–present | label = {{flatlist| * [[Republic Records|Republic]] * [[Island Records|Island]] }} | occupation = {{flatlist| * Rapper * singer }} | website = {{URL|angelhazemusic.com}} }} '''Raykeea Raeen-Roes Wilson''' (born July 10, 1994)<!-- As per the cited source, Wilson was 21 in September 2012 and 22 in October 2013, meaning birth year = 1994 --><ref name="hermionehobytheguardian2012">{{Cite news|title = Angel Haze: 'Right now, no one can beat me'|url = https://www.theguardian.com/music/2012/aug/26/angel-haze-new-york-rapper|newspaper = The Guardian|date = 2012-09-01|access-date = 2016-02-23|issn = 0261-3077|first = Hermione|last = Hoby}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = Interview: Angel Haze, the rapper fighting rape culture|url = http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/10349936/Interview-Angel-Haze-the-rapper-fighting-rape-culture.html|website = Telegraph.co.uk|access-date = 2016-02-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2014/feb/21/angel-haze-interview-my-mum-knew-i-would-tell-everything|title=Angel Haze: 'My mum knew I was going to tell everything'|author=Tom Lamont|date=February 22, 2014|work=The Guardian|accessdate=2018-01-31}}</ref> known professionally as '''Angel Haze''', is an American rapper and singer. In 2012, Wilson released the EP ''Reservation'' and later signed a record deal with [[Universal Republic Records]] before moving to [[Republic Records]].<ref name=":1">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/the-juice/480478/angel-haze-talks-universal-republic-deal-debut-album-azealia-banks|title=Angel Haze Talks Universal Republic Deal, Debut Album, & Azealia Banks Collabo|website=Billboard|access-date=April 18, 2016}}</ref> On December 31, 2013, Wilson released the debut album ''[[Dirty Gold]]'', which featured the singles "Echelon (It's My Way)" and "[[Battle Cry (Angel Haze and Sia song)|Battle Cry]]". Wilson has released a number of mixtapes, including ''[[Reservation (mixtape)|Reservation]]'', which was ranked the sixth-best mixtape of 2012 by Mike Diver of the [[BBC]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/bbcmusic/entries/5aa3dca6-2bb2-32ed-b3df-6b71ef4b1dbb|title=Six of the Best: Mixtapes of 2012|date=December 12, 2012|website=Music Blog}}</ref> Their most recent mixtape is ''Back to the Woods'' (2015).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/music/back-to-the-woods/angel-haze|title=Reviews for Back To The Woods by Angel Haze – Metacritic|work=Metacritic}}</ref>
== Early life == Wilson was born in [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]] to a military family. Wilson's father, who passed away from a gunshot wound before Wilson was born, was [[African American]] and their mother is a [[Cherokee|Native American Cherokee]].<ref name="lamont1">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2014/feb/21/angel-haze-interview-my-mum-knew-i-would-tell-everything|title=Angel Haze: 'My mum knew I was going to tell everything'|last=Lamont|first=Tom|date=February 22, 2014|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=April 19, 2018}}</ref> When Wilson was a young child their mother met a preacher in the [[Apostolic Faith Church|Greater Apostolic Faith]] and she moved into his home with his wife and children, into what Wilson describes as a cult.<ref name="lamont1"/> Growing up in the church, Wilson witnessed [[domestic violence]] and manipulation at a very young age.<ref name="youtube1">{{Citation|last=Sway's Universe|title=Angel Haze Elaborates on Her Experience in Cult Life and Performs "New York"|date=December 20, 2012|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JLxjBTzVqCg|accessdate=April 19, 2018}}</ref><ref name="complex1">{{cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/music/2012/09/who-is-angel-haze/her-relationship-with-religion|title=Who is Angel Haze? Her Relationship With Religion|website=Complex|language=en|access-date=April 19, 2018}}</ref> As a child, Wilson was [[Sexual abuse|sexually abused]] by a man close to the family.<ref name="lamont1"/> Wilson also recalls being told that they would die spontaneously if they didn't behave correctly.<ref name="lamont1"/> In an interview with ''[[The Guardian]]'', Wilson stated: "we all lived in the same community, within 10 minutes of each other. You weren't allowed to talk to anyone outside of that, you weren't allowed to wear jewelry, listen to music, to eat certain things, to date people...you weren't allowed to do pretty much anything."<ref name="macphersonguardian2013">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/jan/31/rapper-angel-haze-religion-rape-survival|title=Rapper Angel Haze on religion, rape, and survival|last=Macpherson|first=Alex|date=January 31, 2013|work=The Guardian|accessdate=June 13, 2013|location=London}}</ref>
Wilson's family moved around a lot, mainly due to their mother running away from the church.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/music/2012/09/who-is-angel-haze/growing-up|title=Who is Angel Haze?Growing Up in Multiple Cities|website=Complex|language=en|access-date=April 19, 2018}}</ref> At one point Wilson's family was living in a shelter and Wilson was teased at school for it.<ref name="complex2">{{cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/music/2012/09/who-is-angel-haze/her-obsession-with-neurology-other-interests|title=Who is Angel Haze?Her Obsession With Neurology and Other Interests|website=Complex|language=en|access-date=April 19, 2018}}</ref> Wilson was also mocked about their clothes at school and had difficulties making friends and connections due to moving around so often switched between [[Homeschooling|homeschool]] and [[State school|public school]] for many years and finished their high school education a year early.<ref name="complex2"/>
After a pastor threatened Wilson's mother, the family left the church and moved to [[Brooklyn]], New York when Wilson was 15 years old.<ref name="rollingstone1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/angel-hazes-no-nonsense-hip-hop-journey-20130808|title=Angel Haze's No-Nonsense Hip-Hop Journey|work=Rolling Stone|access-date=April 19, 2018}}</ref> The pastor of their church told Wilson's family that God was going to kill them and Wilson's family lived in fear for years afterward.<ref name="complex1"/>
Wilson began writing as a form of therapy and expressed an interest in [[creative writing]], [[poetry]] and [[journalism]].<ref name="complex3">{{cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/music/2012/09/who-is-angel-haze/personality|title=Who is Angel Haze?Her Unique Personality|website=Complex|language=en|access-date=April 19, 2018}}</ref> Wilson's first poem was published at the age of 13 after winning a school competition.<ref name="complex3"/> As a child Roe took creative writing lessons and wanted to be a songwriter or [[gospel artist]].<ref name="complex3"/> Eventually, Wilson began making [[YouTube]] videos and [[Freestyle rap|freestyle rapping]] at the age of 18.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/music/2012/09/who-is-angel-haze/taking-rap-seriously|title=Who is Angel Haze?Taking Rap Seriously|website=Complex|language=en|access-date=April 19, 2018}}</ref> Wilson began distributing music on the Internet through sites like [[Tumblr|Tumblr,]] where a fan base began to form.<ref name="lamont1"/>
== Musical career == [[File:Angel Haze live at Øyafestivalen 2013.jpg|thumb|230px|left|Wilson performing live at Øyafestivalen in 2013]]
From 2009 to 2012, Wilson put out a number of [[Mixtape|mixtapes]] for free download on the Internet: ''New Moon'', ''Altered Ego'', ''King'', and ''Voice''. In July 2012, Wilson released the free mixtape ''Reservation'' to critical acclaim, receiving an 88/100 score from Metacritic.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/music/reservation-mixtape/angel-haze|title=Reviews for Reservation [Mixtape] by Angel Haze – Metacritic|work=Metacritic}}</ref> The title ''Reservation'' serves as an homage to Wilson's Native American heritage.<ref name="buzzfeed1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/shannonkeating/the-evolution-of-angel-haze|title=The Evolution Of Angel Haze|work=BuzzFeed|access-date=April 19, 2018|language=en}}</ref> On December 9, the [[BBC]] announced that Wilson had been nominated for the [[Sound of...|Sound of 2013]] poll.<ref name="so13">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p010q6bc/profiles/angelhaze|title=Sound of 2013 Profiles: Angel Haze|publisher=BBC|date=December 9, 2012|accessdate=December 10, 2012}}</ref>
In 2012, Wilson recounted the experience of being sexually assaulted as a child in "Cleaning Out My Closet", a song from the mixtape ''Classick'' that uses segments from [[Eminem]]'s [[Cleanin' Out My Closet|song of the same name]].<ref name=":0"/>
On August 28, 2013, Wilson released "Echelon (It's My Way)" as the lead single from the debut album ''Dirty Gold''. The entire album was leaked on December 18, 2013, prior to scheduled March 2014 release.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rap-up.com/2013/12/18/angel-haze-says-fuck-you-to-label-leaks-her-album/#more-175427|title=Angel Haze Says ‘F**k You’ to Label, Leaks their Album|work=Rap-Up}}</ref> The album release was put forward and it appeared through [[Island Records]] and Republic Records on December 30, 2013, to positive reviews. It had low first-week sales<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/music/dirty-gold/angel-haze|title=Reviews for Dirty Gold by Angel Haze – Metacritic|work=Metacritic}}</ref> of just over 5000 copies sold.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2014/01/angel-haze-addresses-low-record-sales/|title=Angel Haze Isn't Bothered By '''Her''' Low Record Sales – XXL|work=XXL}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.factmag.com/2014/01/07/angel-hazes-dirty-gold-sells-857-copies-in-the-uk-hasnt-charted-in-the-us-billboard-200-chart/|title=Angel Haze's Dirty Gold sold 857 copies first week in the UK, not the Billboard 200 – FACT Magazine: Music News, New Music.|work=FACT Magazine: Music News, New Music.}}</ref> On September 14, 2015, Wilson released the mixtape ''Back to the Woods'' announcing that the project was just "something to share before a sophomore".<ref>{{cite web|title = Stream: Angel Haze's new project Back to the Woods|url = http://consequenceofsound.net/2015/09/stream-angel-hazes-new-project-back-to-the-woods/|website = Consequence of Sound|publisher = |accessdate = January 8, 2016|language = }}</ref> In March 2017 Wilson released "Resurrection".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/hip-hop/7777007/angel-haze-resurrection-video-premiere-interview|title=Angel Haze's 'Resurrection' Video Premiere: The 'Spiritual' Rapper Talks Upcoming Album and Sampling John Mayer|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefader.com/2016/11/22/angel-haze-resurrection-single|title=Angel Haze Has A Point To Prove On “Resurrection”|publisher=}}</ref>
== Artistry ==
=== Influences === After Wilson moved to New York and began listening to [[secular]] music, they became inspired by artists such as [[Eminem]], [[Kanye West]], [[Nicki Minaj]], [[Drake (musician)|Drake]] and [[Lil Wayne]].<ref name="youtube1"/> "The artists that I identify [with] mostly are the ones who are so uncompromisingly themselves," Wilson said in a 2014 ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' interview. "Like, 'fuck you. I don't care what you think about it. This is who I am. And I can either force-feed you this shit or you can take it as you will.'"<ref name="rollingstone1"/>
=== Public image === Wilson raps about themes such as [[homophobia]], [[rape culture]] and [[racism]]. Wilson uses their personal experiences to condemn a culture that breeds the self-harm of queer youth.<ref name="buzzfeed1"/> Wilson has also been open about their experience with [[mental illnesses]] such as [[addiction]], [[Ptsd|PTSD]], [[depression (mood)|depression]] and [[Anorexia nervosa|anorexia]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thefader.com/2015/09/17/angel-haze-back-to-the-woods-interview|title=How Angel Haze Turned Tragedy Into Triumph On Back To The Woods|work=The FADER|access-date=April 19, 2018|language=en}}</ref> in their music and in interviews and social media.
Wilson sees their goal as an artist to reach out to people who are similar to them or going through difficult experiences.<ref name="buzzfeed1"/> Wilson has said, "It's not about the Bible. It's not about going to church. It's not about anything other than that we are all energies connected with a force that's greater than us. It's an energy that's omniscient, it covers the whole world and everybody here is created for a reason. Mine happens to be to make the music and inspire the people who are stuck in dark places."<ref name="billboard1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/hip-hop/7777007/angel-haze-resurrection-video-premiere-interview|title=Angel Haze's 'Resurrection' Video Premiere: The 'Spiritual' Rapper Talks Upcoming Album and Sampling John Mayer|work=Billboard|access-date=April 19, 2018}}</ref>
In a 2014 ''[[Vice Media|Vice]]'' column, Wilson discussed [[cultural appropriation]] and white artists making hip hop. Wilson stated, "There seems to be this hypocrisy, because people want to appropriate black culture but only when it's cool or beneficial to them... And that's the reason that people don't have a right, to some extent, to use black music to their own gains."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://noisey.vice.com/en_uk/article/rzeekj/angel-haze-on-hip-hop-and-cultural-appropriation-2015|title=Angel Haze: "It Feels Like a Punch To The Gut When Someone Takes Our Culture and Runs With It"|date=January 20, 2015|work=Noisey|access-date=April 19, 2018|language=en-uk}}</ref>
== Personal life == Wilson identifies as [[Pansexuality|pansexual]] and as [[agender]] and use the pronoun 'they' for themself.<ref>{{cite web|first=Kim|last=Osorio|title=Angel Haze: What This Up-And-Coming Female MC Says Will Make You Listen|url=http://thesource.com/2012/07/05/angelhazewhatthisup-and-comingfemalemcsayswillmakeyoulisten/|work=''[[The Source (magazine)|The Source]]''|publisher=The NorthStar Group|location=New York City|date=July 5, 2012}}</ref><ref name="auto">{{cite web|first=Shannon|last=Keating|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/shannonkeating/the-evolution-of-angel-haze#.bcWn4ONAX|title=The Evolution Of Angel Haze|date=March 27, 2015|website=[[BuzzFeed]]|publisher=|access-date=April 18, 2016}}</ref> Wilson has said "I'm glad there's an actual woman of color representing [[queer]]ness and pansexuality, someone who is like me in the spotlight."<ref>{{cite web|first=Alexandria|last=Symonds|url=http://www.out.com/entertainment/music/2014/02/04/emancipation-angel-haze|title=EXCLUSIVE: Angel Haze on questioning her family, her sexuality & God|work=[[Out Magazine]]|publisher=[[Here Media]]|location=San Francisco, California|date=February 4, 2014|access-date=April 18, 2016}}</ref> In an interview with ''[[The Guardian]]'', Wilson stated that, "Love is boundary-less. If you can make me feel, if you can make me laugh – and that's hard – then I can be with you. I don't care if you have a vagina or if you're a [[hermaphrodite]] or whatever."<ref name="hermionehobytheguardian2012"/>
In 2014, they were in a relationship with model [[Ireland Baldwin]].<ref>Cavan Sieczkowski, "Angel Haze On Relationship With Ireland Baldwin: ‘We F**k And Friends Don’t F**k’," [https://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/06/27/angel-haze-ireland-baldwin_n_5537001.html HuffPost], 27 June, 2014.</ref> The two broke up a year later.<ref>Gabrielle Korn, "did angel haze and ireland baldwin just break up?," [https://nylon.com/articles/angel-haze-ireland-baldwin-break-up Nylon], 5 February, 2015.</ref>
In 2015 Wilson noted in an interview with ''[[BuzzFeed]]'' that "I feel like my agenderness and my gender identity have evolved",<ref name="auto" /> and a year later explained that "I sound like four people when I get written about as 'they'. It drives me crazy. If you call me 'him' or 'her' it doesn't matter to me. I don’t consider myself of any sex. I consider myself an experience."<ref name=":2">{{cite web|first=David|last=Smyth|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/goingout/music/angel-haze-interview-at-home-i-m-dead-but-on-stage-i-m-god-a3157611.html|title=Angel Haze, interview: 'At home, I’m dead. But on stage, I’m God'|website=[[Evening Standard]]|publisher=[[Daily Mail and General Trust]]|location=London, England|date=January 15, 2016|access-date=September 4, 2016}}</ref>
Wilson covered [[Macklemore & Ryan Lewis|Macklemore's]] "[[Same Love]]" and opened up about their own struggles with family over sexuality in their own interpretation of the song.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/angel-haze-on-dirty-gold-and-her-hippie-aspirations-20131118|title=Angel Haze Wants to Be a Hippie|work=Rolling Stone|access-date=April 19, 2018}}</ref> In a 2017 ''Billboard'' interview Wilson stated, "When I was young . . . I didn't understand what was going on. I didn't understand that I could be attracted to men and women at the same time."<ref name="billboard1"/>
In 2015, Wilson began working on a body image project titled "The Naked Eye," which will incorporate nude photographs and interviews of people with [[body dysmorphia]].<ref name="buzzfeed1"/> The project is aimed at creating a conversation about conventional and mainstream beauty standards.
Wilson is self-taught in [[Cherokee language|Tsalagi]] and celebrates their multiracial heritage.<ref name="buzzfeed1"/>
== Discography == {{Main|Angel Haze discography}} * ''[[Dirty Gold]]'' (2013) * ''[[Back to the Woods (album)|Back to the Woods]]'' (2015)

{{BLP primary sources|date=October 2012}} '''Barbara Crawford Johnson''' is an [[Americans|American]] aeronautical engineer.{{cite web | title = SWE Women - Barbara Crawford Johnson | work = The Society of Women Engineers | accessdate = 2012-10-17 | date = 2008-03-13 | url = http://societyofwomenengineers.swe.org/index.php/employers-q1-2010-career-center-408/46-swe-women-johnson }} == Bio == Barbara was the first woman to graduate with in general engineering with a Bachelor's degree from the University of Illinois in 1946. Additionally, she was the one woman in NASA's engineering team that participated in our achievement to the arrival on the Moon. She conducted significant and important studies on flight dynamics, missile design, wind tunnels, performance analysis, and aerodynamics. Barbara was promoted to the position of chief engineer after only five years. Barbara's noteworthy contribution in the manned space flight programs began with the Apollo Lunar Landing program. In this program she supervised the design and evaluation of the entry monitoring systems for the missions. Barbara represented Rockwell International Space Division in technical meetings with NASA management and astronauts at the Johnson Space Center in Houston, Texas. In 1968, she was appointed the highest position ever achieved by a woman in her department: manager of the Apollo Program. In this position, Barbara oversaw the mission and evaluation requirements, as well as supervising over 100 engineers that worked on the Lunar landing mission and Skylab. Throughout her exceptional career, she received several awards within the world of engineering. After graduating, Barbara worked for North American Aviation. This later became the Space Division of Rockwell International. In 1973, NASA's astronaut Fred Haise Jr. wrote Barbara a letter of commendation. She additionally received a medallion from NASA to commemorate her contribution to the Apollo 11 mission.{{Cite news|url=http://www.bloquetech.com/salas-figuras-ocultas-crawford/|title=Figuras ocultas: Barbara Crawford Johnson - BLOQUETECH|date=2018-10-16|work=BLOQUETECH|access-date=2018-11-29|language=es-ES}} [[File:Barbara at work.jpg|thumb|1974 Society of Women Engineers Achievement Award recipient Barbara Crawford Johnson speaks to co-workers in her office, circa 1970-1974.]]
==Projects== {{BLP unsourced section|date=October 2012}} *The recovery of hypersonic gliders *Lunar reentry vehicle research *Orbital rendezvous *The [[SM-64 Navaho|Navaho missile]] *The Hound Dog air-to-ground missile *The Apollo Lunar Landing Program *Lunar Landing *Skylab{{Cite web|url=https://ethw.org/Oral-History:Barbara_Crawford_Johnson|title=Oral-History:Barbara Crawford Johnson - Engineering and Technology History Wiki|website=ethw.org|language=en|access-date=2018-10-17}} *Apollo-Soyuz *Space Shuttle (responsible for Shuttle system and Orbiter Project mission related analysis). ==Awards== * 1975: The Distinguished Alumni Merit Award, University of Illinois College of Engineering{{Cite web|url=http://engineering.illinois.edu/alumni/distinguished/1975/johnson-barbara|title=Barbara Crawford Johnson|work=Engineering at Illinois|accessdate=2012-10-17}} * 1976: [[Dirk Brouwer Award (American Astronautical Society)|Dirk Brouwer Award]], Americal Astronautical Society{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautical.org/awards/brouwer |title=Dirk Brouwer Award | American Astronautical Society |publisher=Astronautical.org |date=2012-08-20 |accessdate=2012-10-17}} == References == {{Reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Johnson, Barbara, Crawford}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Women in engineering]] [[Category:21st-century American engineers]] [[Category:University of Illinois alumni]] [[Category:NASA people]] [[Category:Apollo program]] {{US-engineer-stub}}

{{about|a musician|his album of the same name|Boz Scaggs (album)}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Boz Scaggs | image = BozSkaggs0449.jpg | caption = In concert in 2006 | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = William Royce Scaggs | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1944|06|08}} | birth_place = [[Canton, Ohio]], [[United States]] | origin = [[Plano, Texas]], United States | instrument = [[Guitar]], [[Human voice|vocals]] | genre = [[Blue-eyed soul]], [[Rock music|rock]], [[blues rock]], [[soft rock]], [[Jazz fusion|jazz rock]] | occupation = [[Singing|Singer]], [[songwriter]], [[guitarist]] | years_active = 1963–present | label = [[Concord Records|Concord]], [[Columbia Records|Columbia]], [[Atlantic Records|Atlantic]], [[Virgin Records|Virgin]], [[429 Records]] | associated_acts = [[Steve Miller Band]], [[Toto (band)|Toto]] | website = [http://www.bozscaggs.com bozscaggs.com] }} '''William Royce '''"'''Boz'''"''' Scaggs''' (born June 8, 1944) is an [[United States|American]] [[singing|singer]], [[songwriter]], and [[guitarist]]. He is most well-known for his worldwide chart topping albums of the late 1970's and [[hit single]]s including "[[Lido Shuffle]]" and the Grammy award winning "[[Lowdown (Boz Scaggs song)|Lowdown]]" from the critically acclaimed album ''[[Silk Degrees]]'' (1976), which peaked at No. 2 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]]. Scaggs continues to write, record music, and tour.{{cite web|url=http://www.bozscaggs.com |title=Boz Scaggs Official Website | Home |publisher=Bozscaggs.com |date= |accessdate=2015-11-04}} ==Early life and career== Scaggs was born in [[Canton, Ohio]], the eldest child of a traveling salesman. Their family moved to [[McAlester, Oklahoma]], then to [[Plano, Texas]] (at that time a farm town), just north of Dallas. He attended a Dallas private school, [[St. Mark's School of Texas]], where schoolmate Mal Buckner gave him the nickname "Bosley", later shortened to "Boz".{{cite web|url=http://www.bozscaggs.org/bozography.htm |title=Boz Scaggs Biography by Ben Fong-Torres |publisher=BozScaggs.org |date=1974-03-10 |accessdate=2015-11-04}} After learning guitar at the age of 12, Scaggs met [[Steve Miller (musician)|Steve Miller]] at St. Mark's School. In 1959, he became the vocalist for Miller's band, the Marksmen. The pair later attended the [[University of Wisconsin–Madison]] together, playing in [[blues]] bands like [[the Ardells]] and the Fabulous Knight Trains. Leaving school, Scaggs briefly joined the burgeoning [[rhythm and blues]] scene in London, then traveled on to Sweden as a solo performer, and in 1965 recorded his solo debut album, ''[[Boz (album)|Boz]]'', which failed commercially. He also had a brief stint with the band the Other Side with [[Mac MacLeod]] and [[Jack Downing (musician)|Jack Downing]]. Returning to the U.S., Scaggs promptly headed for the booming [[Psychedelic rock|psychedelic music]] center of [[San Francisco]] in 1967. Linking up with Steve Miller again, he appeared on the [[Steve Miller Band]]'s first two albums, ''[[Children of the Future (Steve Miller Band album)|Children of the Future]]'' and ''[[Sailor (album)|Sailor]]'' in 1968. Scaggs secured a solo contract with [[Atlantic Records]] in 1968, releasing his second album, ''[[Boz Scaggs (album)|Boz Scaggs]]'', featuring the [[Muscle Shoals Rhythm Section]] and [[session guitarist]] [[Duane Allman]], in 1969. Despite good reviews, this release achieved only moderate sales. He then briefly hooked up with Bay Area band [[Mother Earth (American band)|Mother Earth]] in a supporting role on their second album ''[[Make a Joyful Noise]]'' on guitar and backup vocals. Scaggs then signed with [[Columbia Records]]; his first four albums for Columbia all charted, with his best peaking at No. 81. ==1976–1981: the hit years== In 1976, using [[session musician]]s who later formed [[Toto (band)|Toto]], he recorded ''[[Silk Degrees]]''. The album reached #2 on the US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]], and #1 in a number of other countries, spawning four hit [[single (music)|singles]]: "It's Over", "[[Lowdown (Boz Scaggs song)|Lowdown]]", "What Can I Say", and "[[Lido Shuffle]]", as well as the poignant ballad "[[We're All Alone]]", later recorded by [[Rita Coolidge]] and [[Frankie Valli]]. "Lowdown" sold over one million copies in the US and won the [[Grammy Award for Best R&B Song]], which was shared by Scaggs and [[David Paich]]. A sellout world tour followed, but his follow-up album in 1977 ''[[Down Two Then Left]]'' did not sell as well as ''Silk Degrees'' and neither of its singles reached the Top 40. The 1980 album ''[[Middle Man (album)|Middle Man]]'' spawned two top 20 hits, "Breakdown Dead Ahead" and "Jojo"; and Scaggs enjoyed two more hits in 1980-81: "[[Look What You've Done to Me]]", from ''[[Urban Cowboy]]'' soundtrack, and "[[Miss Sun]]", from a [[greatest hits]] set. Both were US No. 14 hits. ==Later career== Scaggs took a long break from recording and his next album, ''[[Other Roads]]'', did not appear until 1988. "[[Heart of Mine (Boz Scaggs song)|Heart of Mine]]", from ''Other Roads'', is Scaggs' last top-40 hit as of 2018. Also in 1988, he opened the San Francisco [[nightclub]] ''[[Slim's]]'', and remained an owner of the venue as of 2011.{{cite web|author=Jay Barmann |url=http://www.grubstreet.com/2011/06/boz_scaggs_loves_bar_tartine_a.html |title=Boz Scaggs Loves Bar Tartine, and Eats Many a Loaf of Acme Bread |publisher=Grub Street |date= |accessdate=2015-11-04}} From 1989 to 1992, Scaggs joined [[Donald Fagen]], [[Phoebe Snow (musician)|Phoebe Snow]], [[Michael McDonald (singer)|Michael McDonald]] and others in [[The New York Rock and Soul Revue]]. His next solo release was the album ''[[Some Change]]'' in 1994. He issued ''[[Come On Home (album)|Come On Home]]'', an album of [[rhythm and blues]], and ''[[My Time: A Boz Scaggs Anthology]]'', an anthology, in 1997. He garnered good reviews with ''[[Dig (Boz Scaggs album)|Dig]]'' although the CD was released on [[September 11, 2001 attacks|September 11, 2001]].{{Citation needed|date=July 2016}} In May 2003, Scaggs released ''[[But Beautiful (Boz Scaggs album)|But Beautiful]]'', a collection of [[jazz standard]]s that debuted at number one on the jazz chart. In 2008 he released ''Speak Low'', which he described in the liner notes as "a sort of progressive, experimental effort ... along the lines of some of the ideas that Gil Evans explored." During 2004, he released a [[DVD]] and a live 16-track CD ''[[Greatest Hits Live (Boz Scaggs album)|Greatest Hits Live]]'' that was recorded August 2003 at the [[Great American Music Hall]] in San Francisco. After a break in recording, he undertook a series of shows across the US in 2008. Two years later he joined [[Donald Fagen]] and [[Michael McDonald (singer)|Michael McDonald]] for concerts entitled the [[Dukes of September Rhythm Revue]]. Scaggs's next album ''[[Memphis (Boz Scaggs album)|Memphis]]'' was released in March 2013. It was recorded in that Southern American city at the [[Royal Studios]]. The album included some of his favorite compositions from other artists. A tour of the [[United States]], [[Canada]] and [[Japan]] followed the release. Before the year ended, he added live dates across North America and Australia for 2014. In 2015, he released ''A Fool to Care'', a compilation of mostly covers, including "Whispering Pines" with Lucinda Williams, and one original blues composition, "Hell to Pay," performed with [[Bonnie Raitt]]. The album rose to number one on the ''Billboard'' Blues Album chart and number 54 on the Billboard 200.{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/a-fool-to-care-mw0002824086/awards |title=A Fool to Care - Boz Scaggs | Awards |publisher=[[AllMusic]] |date=2015-03-31 |accessdate=2015-11-04}} ==Personal life and family== Scaggs' first marriage was to Carmella Storniola. They had two sons: [[Austin Scaggs|Austin]], a [[music journalism|music journalist]] with a column called "The Smoking Section" in ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', and Oscar, who at age 21 died of a [[heroin overdose]] in 1998.{{cite website|url=http://www.sfgate.com/news/article/Boz-Scaggs-Son-Dies-On-New-Year-s-Eve-Heroin-2954437.php |title=Boz Scaggs' Son Dies On New Year's Eve / Heroin overdose kills 21-year-old |website=SFGate.com |date=January 4, 1999|accessdate=2015-11-04}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/health/article/Heartbroken-Scaggs-Family-Speaks-Out-Against-2952463.php|title=Heartbroken Scaggs Family Speaks Out Against Heroin / Musician calls drug that killed son 'S.F. plague'|website=SFGate.com}} Scaggs and Carmella divorced in 1980,{{cite web|url=http://www.beautifulboz.com/page/63132|title=Boz Scaggs Interview|website=Beautifulboz.com}} and after a child custody battle, they were awarded [[joint custody]] of their sons.{{cite web|url=http://articles.philly.com/1994-09-09/entertainment/25838377_1_silk-degrees-boz-scaggs-parenting|title=Archives - Philly.com|website=articles.philly.com}} Carmella died in February 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Carmella-Scaggs-socialite-and-ex-wife-of-singer-10932897.php|title=Carmella Scaggs, socialite and ex-wife of singer|date=15 February 2017|website=Sfgate.com|accessdate=27 July 2018}} Scaggs and his current wife Dominique (whom he married in 1992){{cite web|url=http://www.therichest.com/celebnetworth/celeb/boz-scaggs-net-worth/|title=Boz Scaggs - Net Work|website=TheRichest - The World's Most Entertaining Site|date=11 January 2012|publisher=}} grow grapes in [[Napa County, California]], and have produced their own wine.{{cite web|url=http://www.scaggsvineyard.com |title=Welcome - Scaggs Vineyards - Organic farming and artisanal winemaking from Mt. Veeder, Napa Valley |website=Scaggsvineyard.com |date= |accessdate=2015-11-04}} ==Discography== === With the Steve Miller Band === {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !Year!!Album!![[Billboard Top 200|US]] |- |1968||''[[Children of the Future (Steve Miller Band album)|Children of the Future]]||134 |- |1968||''[[Sailor (album)|Sailor]]''||24 |} === Solo Albums === {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !Year!!Album!![[Billboard 200|US]]
{{cite web|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/boz-scaggs/chart-history/billboard-200|title=Boz Scaggs Chart History: Billboard 200|work=Billboard|accessdate=August 7, 2018}}!![[Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums|US
R&B]]!!RIAA Certification |- |1965||''[[Boz (album)|Boz]]''||—||—|| |- |1969||''[[Boz Scaggs (album)|Boz Scaggs]]''*||171||—|| |- |1971||''[[Moments (Boz Scaggs album)|Moments]]''||124||—|| |- |1971||''[[Boz Scaggs & Band]]''||198||—|| |- |1972||''[[My Time]]''||138||—|| |- |1974||''[[Slow Dancer]]''||81||—||Gold |- |1976||''[[Silk Degrees]]''||2||6||5xMulti-Platinum |- |1977||''[[Down Two Then Left]]''||11||—||Platinum |- |1980||''[[Middle Man (album)|Middle Man]]''||8||36||Platinum |- |1988||''[[Other Roads]]''||47||—|| |- |1996||''[[Fade into Light]]''||—||—|| |- |1997||''[[Come On Home (album)|Come On Home]]''||94||—|| |- |2001||''[[Dig (Boz Scaggs album)|Dig]]''||146||—|| |- |2002||''Sail on White Moon''|||||| |- |2003||''[[But Beautiful (Boz Scaggs album)|But Beautiful]]''||167||—|| |- |2008||''Speak Low''||128||—|| |- |2013||''[[Memphis (Boz Scaggs album)|Memphis]]''{{cite web |last=Baltin |first=Steve |date=2013-01-14 |title=Boz Scaggs to Release First New Album in Five Years in March | Music News |publisher=Rolling Stone |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/boz-scaggs-to-release-first-new-album-in-five-years-in-march-20130114 |accessdate=2013-03-09}}||17||—|| |- |2015||''[[A Fool to Care]]''||54||—|| |- |2018||''[[Out of the Blues (album)|Out of the Blues]]''{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Out-Blues-Boz-Scaggs/dp/B07CXC3312|title=Boz Scaggs – Out of the Blues|website=[[Amazon.com]]|accessdate=May 18, 2018}}||82||—|| |} * While the 1969 self-titled Atlantic album failed to chart upon initial release, it peaked at #171 when reissued in 1974. Three years later the album was reissued once again, this time in a remixed form. This version, however, only bubbled under the Billboard 200, reaching #209. === Compilation Albums === {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !Year!!Album!![[Billboard 200|US]]
{{cite web|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/boz-scaggs/chart-history/billboard-200|title=Boz Scaggs Chart History: Billboard 200|work=Billboard|accessdate=August 7, 2018}}!![[Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums|US
R&B]]!!RIAA Certification |- |1980||''[[Hits! (Boz Scaggs album)|Hits!]]''||24||—||Platinum |- |1994||''[[Some Change]]''||91||—|| |- |1997||''[[My Time: A Boz Scaggs Anthology]]''||—||—|| |- 1999 ''[[songs for you]] |2004||''[[Greatest Hits Live (Boz Scaggs album)|Greatest Hits Live]]''||—||—|| |- |2013||''[[The Essential Boz Scaggs]]''||—||—|| |} ===Singles=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !Year !Title ![[Billboard Hot 100|US]] ![[UK Singles Chart|UK]]{{cite book | last= Roberts | first= David | date= 2006 | title= British Hit Singles & Albums | edition= 19th | publisher= Guinness World Records Limited | location= London | isbn= 1-904994-10-5 | page= 483}} ![[Kent Music Report|AU]] !Album |- |rowspan="2"|1971 |"We Were Always Sweethearts" |61 |— |— |rowspan="2"|''[[Moments (Boz Scaggs album)|Moments]]'' |- |"Near You" |96 |— |— |- |1972 |"Dinah Flo" |86 |— |— |''[[My Time]]'' |- |rowspan="3"|1976 |"It's Over" |38 |— |63 |rowspan="4"|''[[Silk Degrees]]'' |- |"[[Lowdown (Boz Scaggs song)|Lowdown]]" |3 |28 |54 |- |"What Can I Say" |42 |10 |2 |- |rowspan="2"|1977 |"[[Lido Shuffle]]" |11 |13 |2 |- |"Hard Times" |58 |— |40 |rowspan="2"|''[[Down Two Then Left]]'' |- |1978 |"Hollywood" |49 |33 |43 |- |rowspan="4"|1980 |"[[Breakdown Dead Ahead]]" |15 |— |64 |rowspan="2"|''[[Middle Man (album)|Middle Man]]'' |- |"Jojo" |17 |— |73 |- |"[[Look What You've Done to Me]]" |14 |— |— |''[[Urban Cowboy]]'' (soundtrack) |- |"[[Miss Sun]]" |14 |— |— |''[[Hits! (Boz Scaggs album)|Hits!]]'' |- |1988 |"Heart of Mine" |35 |— |60 |''[[Other Roads]]'' |- |colspan="6"|Source:{{cite book | last= Strong | first= Martin C. | date= 2000 | title= The Great Rock {{use mdy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox person |image = BrookeTheiss.jpg | |imagesize = 200px | |caption = Theiss at a celebrity autograph collector's convention in Burbank, California. | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1969|10|23|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Palos Verdes]], [[California]], U.S. | occupation = Actress | years_active = 1987-present | parents = [[Dick Thies]]
[[Kathleen Mitchell]] | spouse = {{marriage|[[Bryan Geneese]]|1994}} | children = 2 }} '''Brooke Theiss-Genesse''' (born October 23, 1969) is an American actress who has starred in film and on television. ==Early life== Theiss was born in [[Palos Verdes, California]] to actors [[Dick Thies]] and [[Kathleen Mitchell]]. She changed the spelling of her surname to make it easier to spell.Jerry Buck, [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1917&dat=19890721&id=1HEhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=W4gFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2196,4677244" | online] Brooke Theiss Works Hard to Overcome Effects of Dyslexia," Schenectady Gazette (21 July 1989): 35. ==Career== Theiss’ first film role was in 1988's ''[[Little Nikita]]'', but later that year, Brooke's big role came in the hit horror movie ''[[A Nightmare on Elm Street 4: The Dream Master]]'' as Debbie Stevens. Her most recent movie is [[2004 in film|2004]]'s ''[[Catwoman (film)|Catwoman]]''. Brooke's best known TV role is in the 1980s TV series ''[[Just the Ten of Us]]'' as Wendy Lubbock from 1988 to 1990. She also starred in the 1990s TV series ''[[Good & Evil]]'', ''[[Home Free (1993 TV series)|Home Free]]'' and in ''[[The Amanda Show]]'' from 1999 to 2000. Theiss has made guest appearances in numerous television shows, including: ''[[Growing Pains]]'' (she played Wendy Lubbock); ''[[Blossom (TV series)|Blossom]]''; ''[[Parker Lewis Can't Lose]]''; ''[[Beverly Hills, 90210]]''; ''[[American Dreams]]''; and ''[[Cold Squad]]''. She also portrayed the character of Maxie from [[Maxie's World]] in several commercials for the popular doll. In 2010 Theiss participated in the documentary ''[[Never Sleep Again: The Elm Street Legacy]]'' discussing her experiences while filming her role in ''[[A Nightmare on Elm Street 4: The Dream Master]]''. ==Personal life== Theiss has been married to [[Canada|Canadian]] actor Bryan Genesse since 1994. They have one son, Mitchell Victor (born July 15, 1995) and one daughter, Aubrey Ann (born October 21, 2008). Theiss has [[dyslexia]].Jerry Buck, [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1917&dat=19890721&id=1HEhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=W4gFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2196,4677244" | online] Brooke Theiss Works Hard to Overcome Effects of Dyslexia," Schenectady Gazette (21 July 1989): 35. ==Filmography== ===Movies=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! {{other people||Christopher Evans (disambiguation){{!}}Christopher Evans}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Christopher Evans | image = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1987}} | birth_name = Christopher Evans Kaweesi | other_names = Chris Evans | birth_place = [[Uganda]] | death_date = | death_place = | education = '''General Education'''
''St. Mary's Boarding Secondary School Kitende'', [[Kajjansi]], [[Wakiso District]], Uganda | occupation = Musician, entertainer | years_active = 2007 – present | nationality = Ugandan | citizenship = [[Uganda]] | residence = [[Kampala, Uganda]] | known_for = Music | relatives = Gertrude Mirembe (Sister)
Samuel Mwesigwa (Paternal Uncle) }} '''Christopher Evans''' (born '''Christopher Evans Kaweesi'''), but commonly known as '''Chris Evans''', is a [[Ugandan]] [[songwriter]], [[recording artist|recording]] and [[performing artist]]. He composes and sings in a genre of Ugandan music known as [[Kidandali]].{{cite web| url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/Magazines/Life/Chris-Evans--I-m-unlucky-in-love/689856-2435846-2dk4ri/index.html |title=Chris Evans: I’m unlucky in love |accessdate=6 October 2017 |date=31 August 2014 | first=Edgar | last=Batte |newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]] |location=Kampala}} ==Overview== Chris Evans is one of Uganda's most popular musicians in the 21st century. In July 2013, BigEye.Ug, a Ugandan music website listed him as one of the ''256 Best Ugandan Music Artistes Of All Time''.{{cite web| url=http://bigeye.ug/256-best-ugandan-music-artistes-of-all-time/|first=Ian|last=Ortega|title=256 Best Ugandan Music Artistes Of All Time|date=3 July 2013|accessdate=31 August 2014| publisher=BigEye.Ug}} Chris Evans sings primarily in his native [[Luganda]]. {{asof|January 2014}}, he had released about ten singles including:{{cite web|title=Chris Evans In Steady Climb| url=http://www.observer.ug/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=24114:chris-evans-in-steady-climb |date=10 March 2013|accessdate=31 August 2014|newspaper=[[The Observer (Uganda)]] |location=Kampala | first=Abu-Baker|last=Mulumba }} {{columns-list|colwidth=22em| * Ow'ekisa * Rihanna * Kankole Byenkola * Ndikusasulaki * Bwolonda * Abafumbo * Mulungi * Nsaasira }} In 2015 Evans teamed up with [[Rema Namakula]] to compose, record and perform a [[duet]] named [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pVBTnY0tzC8 Linda] (translates as "Wait" in Luganda). The single received the "Best RnB Song" at the "HiPipo Music Awards" in 2015, at a ceremony held at the [[Kampala Serena Hotel]].{{cite web| accessdate=6 October 2017 | url=http://www.411ug.com/2016/01/chris-evans-praises-rema-namakula-as.html |title=Chris Evans Praises Rema Namakula As 'Linda' Wins HiPipo Award | date=January 2016 |publisher=411Ug.com |author=411Ug.com |location=Kampala}} ==Background== Christopher Evans Kaweesi was born to '''Christopher Kakooza''', a construction worker and '''Mrs. Kakooza''', a housewife. His mother died while he was still a baby and his father died when Kaweesi was about 13 or 14 years old. He paid for his elementary and middle school education by performing menial jobs at construction sites and at school. He passed his O-Level examinations with flying colors, scoring 14 points in 8 subjects (the best possible score is 8). His paternal uncle, sponsored his A-Level education at ''St. Mary’s Boarding Secondary School, Kitende'', a good residential mixed high school, in [[Kajjansi]], off of the [[Kampala]]-[[Entebbe]] Road. At Kitende, Kaweesi studies [[Physics]], [[Chemistry]] and [[Biology]], with [[Mathematics]] as a minor subject. He was admitted to [[Makerere University]] on a [[Uganda Government]] scholarship to study [[Agriculture]]. He enrolled, attended classes, but never graduated. Instead, he used the contacts at the university, to launch his musical career. ==See also== * [[Juliana Kanyomozi]] * [[Jose Chameleon]] * [[Rema Namakula]] * [[Afrigo Band]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Evans, Christopher}} [[Category:Ugandan musicians]] [[Category:Ugandan male singers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1987 births]] [[Category:Ganda people]] [[Category:People from Wakiso District]] [[Category:People from Central Region, Uganda]] [[Category:Ugandan songwriters]]

{{Expand Spanish|Cipitío|topic=culture|date=March 2009}} <!--[[Image:Cipitio.jpg|right|thumb|250px|Cipitio is the most popular character of Salvadoran mythology.]]-->
'''Cipitio''' is a legendary character found in [[El Salvador|salvadoran]] folklore revolving around the [[Siguanaba]] and [[Cadejo]] legends. He is generally portrayed as an 8- to 10-year-old boy with a big conical wizard hat. His name is taken from the [[Nahuatl]] word for child: "Cipit" or "Cipote". Some also relate his name to the deity [[Xipe Totec]].
According to the legend, he is the son of a forbidden romance between an indigenous Mesoamerican queen called Sihuehuet or Ziguet, now commonly known as La [[Siguanaba]], and "Lucero de la mañana" (Lúcifer Morningstar). Cipitio is the child of this affair. When Ziguet's husband found out about this affair he sought the assistance of the very powerful god [[Teotl]]. Ziguet and ''Cipitio'' were cursed and condemned by [[Teotl]]. Cipitio was going to live forever as a small boy with his feet in backwards position, as a reminder of the twisted and illicit affair of his parents. Stories are told of farmers that come to their fields and find the footsteps of a boy, but eventually get lost following them because, not knowing that '''Cipitio''' has his feet backwards, they follow them in the wrong direction.<ref>Kampwirth and Gonzalez 173.</ref>
'''Cipitio''' is represented as liking to eat ashes,<ref>Kephart.</ref> throwing pebbles to beautiful ladies,<ref>Cordova 19.</ref> and likes to eat a variety of [[banana]] called "Guineo Majoncho". He could also "[[Teleportation|Teleport]]" anywhere he wants.
A couple of short stories with this character can be found in the book ''Cuentos de Cipotes'' by the Salvadoran writer and poet Salvador [[Salarrué]].
In a TV show for the Salvadoran Educational Television Station he is portrayed by Rolando Meléndez, who has played the role for several seasons. Each episode features the problems that Salvadoran children find in their communities, families and schools, Cipitio helps them while teaching morals and values.
==See also== *[[Curupira]] *[[Caipora]]
==Notes== <references/>
==Bibliography== *Cordova, Carlos (2005). ''The Salvadoran American''. Westport: Greenwood Press. *Kampwirth, Karen and Victoria Gonzalez (2001). ''Radical Women in Latin America: Left and Right''. State College: Penn State University Press. *Kephart, Beth (2003). ''Still Love in Strange Places''. New York: Norton.
[[Category:Mythological characters]] [[Category:Salvadoran mythology]]

revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=July 2016}} {{Infobox character | color = #001 | color text = white | name = Darkman | series = [[Darkman]] | image = | image_size = 250px | first = ''[[Darkman]]'' | creator = [[Sam Raimi]] | portrayer = [[Liam Neeson]] (''Darkman'')
[[Arnold Vosloo]] (''Darkman II: The Return of Durant'' and ''Darkman III: Die Darkman Die'') | fullname = Peyton Westlake | alias = Dr. Peyton Westlake | gender = Male | occupation = Former [[scientist]]
[[Vigilante]] | significantother = Julie Hastings | lbl21 = Abilities |data21 = Expert scientist
Master of disguise and stealth
Skilled hand-to-hand combatant
Genius-level intelligence
Enhanced strength, speed, agility, and stamina
Use of synthetic skin
Immunity to pain |}} '''Darkman''' is a [[title character]] and the [[protagonist]] of the 1990 superhero film ''[[Darkman]]'' and its sequels, ''[[Darkman II: The Return of Durant]]'' and ''[[Darkman III: Die Darkman Die]]''. The character originated in a short story written by the film's director, [[Sam Raimi]], titled "The Darkman," and is based on the [[Universal Pictures]]' [[Universal Monsters|movie monsters]] while retaining traits of the DC Comics World War II disfigured hero [[Unknown Soldier (DC Comics)|the Unknown Soldier]]. He was portrayed by [[Liam Neeson]] in the original film and [[Arnold Vosloo]] in the sequels. == Fictional character biography == In the third film and the un-aired [[television pilot]], his biography is slightly [[retcon]]ned, but the character's canonical history is as such: Peyton Westlake was a mild-mannered and brilliant scientist working on a synthetic "skin" capable of aiding burn victims. He had a good relationship with district attorney Julie Hastings, who indirectly caused his injuries by telling corrupt developer Louis Strack, Jr. that he could not build his "city of the future" without a permission document from Westlake's laboratory. At this, Strack hired sadistic mobster [[Robert G. Durant]] to get the document and in the process, Durant and his gang brutally disfigured Westlake, killed his assistant and destroyed his lab. Julie believed he was dead and a funeral was held, but Westlake's hideous body was placed in a clinic that was used for various experiments to sever Westlake's [[pain receptors]], which enhances his strength but leaves him unable to feel tactile sensations. The experiments, however, affected Westlake's mental stability and he became an impulsive, bipolar, sarcastic, and violent man. Westlake escaped the clinic and sought refuge in an abandoned building in the film's city. He hid his grotesque appearance with bandages and a [[trenchcoat]] and used his synthetic skin, which only lasts 99 minutes in the light. He managed to rebuild a relationship with Julie, claiming he survived his "accident" and was constantly fleeing so that she does not see his true face. As "Darkman", he begins ruining Durant's illegal activities by framing his gang so Durant kills his own men, including his possible implied lover. After discovering the culprit is Darkman, Durant attempts to kill him from a helicopter using a grenade launcher. Darkman manages to defeat his archenemy by clinging to the helicopter and using his strength to pull it into a tunnel and explode the chopper. Darkman gratifyingly yells "Burn in Hell!". After this, Darkman poses as Durant in order to infiltrate Strack's new skyscraper, which was the reason the developer hired Durant in the first place. Strack suspects Darkman will come after him and takes Julie hostage. Strack suggests they join forces but when he refuses the battle atop the skyscraper. Darkman has the chance to spare his life but instead throws Strack to his death. Believing he has become too much of a monster to be with Julie, that he abandons her, vowing to become a [[vigilante]] and bringer of [[justice]]. After a year of crimefighting, Darkman is shocked to discover that Durant is alive and back in town and that he must again battle his archenemy. He also wishes to avenge a scientist named Brinkman, who he had been partnering with in order to perfect his synthetic skin so he may lead a normal life. After defeating Durant, Darkman found a new enemy in drug lord Peter Rooker who proved to be his most powerful adversary after going through a process that makes his strength equal to Darkman's. Darkman managed to bring down Rooker by posing as him but felt conflicted as he fell in love with Rooker's wife and children, who he had to abandon as well to resume his life as a vigilante. Beforehand, however, he finally manages to perfect his synthetic skin but uses the only sample to heal Rooker's daughter. == Powers and abilities == Due to clinical experiments, the [[nerve ending]]s connected to Darkman's skin have been severed, [[Congenital insensitivity to pain|rendering him immune to pain]], but unable to feel [[physical sensations]]. Additionally, to compensate for his loss of physical feelings, adrenaline flows unchecked through Darkman's body, enhancing his physical strength, speed, agility, reflexes, stamina, and durability. Using his synthetic skin, Darkman is able to pose as criminals, imitate their voices, and trick them into engineering their own downfall. He's also a skilled hand-to-hand combatant, and an expert in the fields of science with a genius-level intellect. == Personality == Darkman possesses similar ethics to those of a [[superhero]], such as not harming the innocent, but has the tenacity and impulsiveness of a psychopath, as demonstrated when he revels in the suffering of criminals. He also has a dangerous temper, as seen in ''Darkman'' when he (disguised as his former self) breaks the fingers of an obnoxious carnival worker for refusing to give Julie Hastings the prized elephant. When Julie refuses the prize, he remarks, furiously, '''''"Take''''' the fucking elephant!" When a cat hisses at him, he is enraged and argues with the cat, and accuses it of thinking he is a "freak of nature." Despite his temper and preference for violence, Darkman also has a morbid sense of humor in sticky situations. For example, Darkman breaks into a business meeting while attached to Durant's chopper. He remarks to the businessman, "Excuse me!" before being pulled off again, and when Strack begs for mercy, stating murder will haunt his conscience. Darkman, after only some hesitation, drops him to his death and remarks, "I'm learning to live with a ''lot'' of things." == Films == === ''Darkman'' === {{main article|Darkman}} This film documents Darkman's origins and his relationship with Julie, and systematically showing his transformation into a vengeful criminal killer and his first battle with Durant and the businessman Strack. === ''Darkman II: The Return of Durant'' === {{main article|Darkman II: The Return of Durant}} Durant survives his ordeal from the first film and plans to take over the city using futuristic weaponry. Only Darkman can stop his archenemy and avenge one of Durant's latest victims. === ''Darkman III: Die Darkman Die'' === {{main article|Darkman III: Die Darkman Die}} Drug lord Peter Rooker allies with a scientist who also worked on Darkman's superhuman strength and invulnerability. He invents a steroid that gives test subjects superhuman strength, but leaves them mentally unstable. Darkman then poses as Rooker to foil his plan, but ends up having to save the villain's family. {{Darkman}} [[Category:Characters created by Sam Raimi]] [[Category:Fictional vigilantes]] [[Category:Fictional scientists]] [[Category:Fictional characters with superhuman strength]] [[Category:Fictional characters who can move at superhuman speeds]] [[Category:Fictional characters with neurological or psychological disorders]] [[Category:Film superheroes]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 1990]] [[Category:Fictional characters with disfigurements]]

{{Distinguish|Devletşah Hatun}} {{Ottoman Turkish name|Devlet|Hatun}} {{Infobox royalty |name = Devlet Hātūn
دولت خاتون |title = Tacü'l-havatin{{cite book |first=Necdet |last=Sakaoğlu|title=Bu mülkün kadın sultanları: Vâlide sultanlar, hâtunlar, hasekiler, kadınefendiler, sultanefendiler|url=https://books.google.com/?id=6WUMAQAAMAAJ&q=havatin+hatun&dq=havatin+hatun|publisher=Oğlak Yayıncılık|year=2008|pages=60–61|isbn=978-9-753-29623-6}}
Sultanü'l-havatin
Seyyidetü'l-muhadderat |image = Devlet Hatun Turbesi2.jpg |caption = Devlet Hatun's [[Türbe]] at [[Bursa]] |succession = [[Hatun|Valide Hatun]] of the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman Sultanate]] |reign = 5 July 1413 – 23 January 1414 |reign-type = Tenure |predecessor = [[Nilüfer Hatun]] |successor = [[Emine Hatun]] |birth_name = Daulat bint-i Abd Allah |birth_date = {{circa}} (?) |birth_place = [[Kütahya]], [[Germiyan dynasty]] |death_date = 23 January 1414 |death_place = [[Bursa]], [[Ottoman Empire]] |death_cause = |burial_place = Devlet Hatun Türbesi, [[Bursa]] |religion = [[Islam]] |spouse = [[Bayezid I]] |issue = [[Mehmed I]][[:tr:İsmail Hakkı Uzunçarşılı|Uzunçarşılı, İ. H.]], ''[[Kütahya]] Şehri'', p. 48, İstanbul State Printing Office, 1932. }} '''Devlet Hatun''' (full name '''Tâcü'l-havatin Devlet Hâtun bint-i Abdullah'''; died 23 January 1414) was the twelfth[https://web.archive.org/web/20020616202944/http://www.4dw.net/royalark/Turkey/turkey2.htm The Imperial House of Osman] wife of [[List of Sultans of the Ottoman Empire|Ottoman Sultan]] [[Bayezid I]] and the mother of [[Mehmed I]].{{cite book|author=Ahmed Akgündüz, Said Öztürk|title=Ottoman History: Misperceptions and Truths|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WKfIAgAAQBAJ|year=2011|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-9-090-26108-9}} ==Biography== Devlet Hatun was the twelfth and last wife of [[Ottoman Sultan]] [[Bayezid I]] and the mother of Bayezid's successor, [[Mehmed I]]. Her name in her ''vakfîyya'' is registered as '''Daulât bint-i Abd'Allah.''' This implies that the mother of Mehmed I was of non-Turkish origin. Although the sign at her tomb (see image in next section) says that ''Devlet'' was the daughter of a Germiyanid (i.e. Turkic) prince, she was ethnically of non-Turkish origin. Since both ''Devlet Hâtun,'' and [[Devletşah Hatun|''Devlet-Şâh Hâtun'']] died in 1414, she is frequently confused with ''Devlet-Şâh Hâtun,'' the daughter of [[Süleyman of Germiyan]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20020616202944/http://www.4dw.net/royalark/Turkey/turkey2.htm The Imperial House of Osman - 2] Devlet Hatun died on 23 January 1414 and was buried at the Devlet Hatun Tomb (Türbesi) in [[Bursa]]. ===Burial place=== [[File:Devlet Hatun Türbesi - Bursa (1).jpg|thumb|Inscription at the entrance of "Devlet [[Hatun|Hātûn]] [[Türbe]]" states that she was a [[Germiyanid]] and her mother was a granddaughter of [[Mawlana Rumi]]. "Devlet Hātûn Türbe" had been constructed by Mehmed I in memory of his mother, Devlet Hātûn. According to the inscription she died on 1412. She is frequently being confused with [[Devletşah Hatun]].]] The tomb of Devlet Hatun stands alone in Bursa neighbourhoods separate from the mosque complexes that contained the tombs of the sultans and other members of the dynasty, following two royal mothers, [[Nilüfer Hatun]] and [[Gülçiçek Hatun]]. It is well tended by the Bursa neighborhood in which it is situated and functions as a local pilgrimage site. The sign outside her tomb gives the following details: {{verse translation|lang=tr |V. padişah Çelebi Mehmet yaptırmıştır. Devlet Hatun, Yıldırım Beyazıtın karısı ve Çelebi Sultan Mehmedin annesidir. Germiyan beyinin kızıdır Devlet Hatunun annesi Mevlâna Celâleddini Rum-i'nin torunudur. Devlet Hatun 1412 yılında ölmüştür.[http://bursayitanitiyoruz.com/arsiv/icerikresim/64b.JPG Board located outside the mausoleum of Devlet Hatun] |It was built by Sultan Mehmed I. Devlet Hatun was the wife of Sultan Bayezid I and the mother of Sultan Mehmed I. She was the daughter of a [[Germiyanid]] prince.{{efn|According to [[:tr:İsmail Hakkı Uzunçarşılı|İ. H. Uzunçarşılı]] in ''Osmanlı Tarihi;'' İ. H. Danişmend in ''Kronoloji;'' [[:tr:Yılmaz Öztuna|Y. Öztuna]] in ''Türkiye Tarihi'' on the other hand, she was the daughter of [[:tr:Germiyanoğlu Süleyman Şah|Süleyman Şah]] of the [[Germiyanids]].}} Her mother was the granddaughter of [[Rumi|Mevlâna Celâleddini Rumi]]. Devlet Hatun died in 1412.}} ==Gallery== Devlet Hatun Türbesi - Bursa (2).jpg|Information board outside the tomb of Devlet Hatun in Bursa Devlet Hatun Türbesi - Bursa (3).jpg|Information borad outside the tomb of Devlet Hatun in Bursa Devlet Hatun Türbesi - Bursa (4).jpg|Devlet Hatun's tomb covered by a stone construction ==See also== *[[Ottoman Empire]] *[[Ottoman dynasty]] *[[Ottoman family tree]] *[[List of Valide Sultans]] *[[List of sultans of the Ottoman Empire]] *[[Line of succession to the Ottoman throne]] *[[Ottoman Emperors family tree]] (simplified) *[[List of consorts of the Ottoman Sultans]] ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== *[[Leslie Peirce|Peirce, Leslie P.]], The Imperial Harem: Women and Sovereignty in the Ottoman Empire, [[Oxford University Press]], 1993, {{ISBN|0-19-508677-5}} (paperback). *Yavuz Bahadıroğlu, Resimli Osmanlı Tarihi, Nesil Yayınları ''(Ottoman History with Illustrations, Nesil Publications)'', 15th Ed., 2009, {{ISBN|978-975-269-299-2}} (Hardcover). {{s-start}} {{s-roy|tr}} {{s-bef|before=[[Nilüfer Hatun]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Valide Sultan|Valide Hâtun]]|years= 5 July 1413 – January 1414}} {{s-aft|after=[[Emine Hatun]]}} {{s-end}} {{Ottoman Dynasty}} {{Mothers of the Ottoman Sultans}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Devlet Hatun}} [[Category:1365 births]] [[Category:1412 deaths]] [[Category:Wives of Ottoman Sultans]] [[Category:14th-century people of the Ottoman Empire]] [[Category:14th-century women of the Ottoman Empire]] [[Category:15th-century people of the Ottoman Empire]] [[Category:15th-century women of the Ottoman Empire]] [[Category:Princesses]] [[Category:People from Kütahya]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{Use British English|date=February 2018}} '''Dinah Elizabeth, Lady Pearce''' ({{nee|Sowter}}; 1836–1918) was the daughter of Robert Sowter of Gravesend. She married [[Sir William Pearce, 1st Baronet|William Pearce]], who had at an early age shown himself to be an outstanding ship builder and by 28 was manager of Messrs Robert Napier and Sons. They set up home in [[Govan]] and occupied John Elder's villa for many years which was demolished to make for the Princes Dock. From there they moved to [[Wemyss Bay]] further down the west coast of Scotland.
As the wife of a successful man she was required to entertain on a regular basis but she did not allow her privileged position to stop her becoming involved in the lives of ordinary Govan people. She believed until her death that [[working people]] had been let down by the government. Her husband became MP for Govan in 1885 and became a [[Pearce baronets|baronet]] two years later. Sir William was at the peak of his career and had by then become owner of [[Fairfield Shipbuilding and Engineering Company|Fairfield Shipyard Company]] which was by then a world leader. She is particularly remembered for her involvement in helping to set up the well-known project 'Fresh-Air-Fortnight' which afforded the opportunity for sick children to have a holiday usually at the seaside but also in the country in order to help their recovery. She was on the school board of Govan Parish from 1873 and during that time argued for female representation on school boards. It was said of Lady Pearce, "Any community was well off where there was a 'Good Angel' in the district, with a liberal heart and a readiness to help forward the best interest of the people and the district".<ref name=":1" />
She had a strong, enduring friendship with [[Margaret Macgregor]],<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Zs6qBgAAQBAJ|title=The Biographical Dictionary of Scottish Women|last=Ewan|first=Elizabeth L.|last2=Innes|first2=Sue|last3=Reynolds|first3=Sian|last4=Pipes|first4=Rose|date=2006-03-08|publisher=Edinburgh University Press|isbn=9780748626601|language=en}}</ref> and employed Margaret as the lady superintendent of the [[Fairfield Works Mission]], whose headquarters were in Harmony Row. Lady Pearce became more deeply involved in religion through her friendship with Margaret. Like Margaret, she was non-sectarian in her approach to her philanthropy and made contributions to all the churches. After Margaret's death, Lady Pearce had a church erected in Margaret's memory, the [[Margaret Macgregor Memorial Church]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=|title=Death of Lady Pearce – Govan's Lady Bountiful – A Discerning Philanthropist|last=|first=|date=10 May 1918|work=Govan Press|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
In 1906 Lady Pearce built the [[Pearce Institute]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://scotcities.com/cathcart/pearceinstitute_sketch.jpg|title=Sketch of Pearce Institute|last=|first=|date=|website=Scotcities|publisher=|access-date=2 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.pearceinstitute.org.uk|title=Home - Pearce Institute|website=Pearce Institute|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-02}}</ref> as a gift to the people of Govan. It is a beautiful A-listed building containing a public hall, library and other rooms. She was a generous supporter of the Govan Press fund and was concerned about the wellbeing of soldiers, disabled children and anyone suffering hardship. To the end she continued to have an interest in the work of the Pearce institute.
She is also known for leaving an endowment in her will to support St Johns College, Durham.<ref>Whiting, C.E. (1932) The University of Durham 1832-1932. (London: The Sheldon Press) pp.173-174</ref>
She died at the age of 82 in 1918 at St Brandon's Wimbledon, where she had lived for many years.<ref name=":0" />
== References == <references />
{{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pearce, Dinah Elizabeth}} [[Category:1836 births]] [[Category:1918 deaths]] [[Category:People from Govan]] [[Category:20th-century Scottish people]] [[Category:20th-century Scottish women]] [[Category:19th-century Scottish people]] [[Category:19th-century Scottish women]] [[Category:British philanthropists]] [[Category:Wives of baronets]] [[Category:Women philanthropists]]
